author: andrea_nicolotti
post: Hugh, the difference between herringbone and chevron, in the textile language AMONG HISTORIANS OF TEXTILES is not what you say. Herringbone is used to identify a kind of chevron, a “warp chevron” (as in the shroud). But as “herringbone” is not so well accepted in scientifical language, it is better to say, describing the shroud, “chevron twill” or “warp chevron twill”. What you call herringbone, defined by the alternate staggers of the weft threads, must be called “broken chevron twill” (that could be either a warp chevron or a weft chevron). I know that the matter is complicated, but the language among historians and among experts of MODERN weawing is not the same..
title: Weaving Fan a.k.a. Colin Berry?
